Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW required for nSPV

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: prepare yourselves üöÄ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: any chain that wants to scale up to a lot of users will need superlight clients

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: could this work on Z?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it could work to validate that utxo is valid very efficiently, but the mechanics of signing ztx, that is a separate problem

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once the zsigning is solved for lite client, then the issue of verifying utxo can use nSPV

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: awesome.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: basically the problem of "given a txid, prove that it really was confirmed in the blockchain", the standard SPV node would need all blockheaders to make sure they all connect and match the longest chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nSPV just needs the blockheaders from the prior notarization to the next notarization, ie. about 10 headers per utxo

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so instead of needed 2GB of headers for a million blocks, 20kb per utxo

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: yea that's a huge improvement

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: even 100 utxos in a wallet would be 2MB of headers data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and most wallets have 10 or less, a frequent rewards collection usually leads to a single utxo

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so 20KB vs 2GB

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: plus the normal txproofs ( a few kb)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and there is no need to query N different nodes to make sure it is valid (statistically) as the notarization data cannot be faked

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: so a standard SPV right now uses 2GB of data to verify 1 tx?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: an SPV wallet (not electrum which is an API wallet) would need all the headers to independently validate any txid

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: most would store it locally, so it is a onetime thing, but still that is a lot of data

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: oh i was mixin it up with electrum

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: equihash coins have 2kb, bitcoin protocol is 80 bytes per header

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it will essentially give electrum api wallet performance without any servers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only for coins with dPoW

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the existing p2p network would be able to support hundreds of thousands, or even millions of nSPV clients

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: very good, grats for figuring it out ü§ù

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we still need to implement it, but since it is so simple, it wont require any major work on top of an existing SPV client

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: if someone can do it it's you :pirate:

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also, it actually requires a komodo ecosystem coin to work that is notarized, just notarization wont be enough as it requires additional daemon support

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: a new one or an existing one?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what do you mean?

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: i mean each coin that wants to use nSPV will need a new second coin?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no, no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i mean a coin that just has dPoW is not enough

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it would need to be a komodo runtime or sourcecode fork

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: ah okay clear

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and if sourcecode fork would need the nSPV specific extensions

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: get it now üóí

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the entire p2p network will be supporting all the nSPV nodes, with a bit more workload by the addressindex=1 spentindex=1 nodes

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: are there any coins with dPow now that are not komodo ecosystem coins?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, we have several, CHIPS, GAME, EMC2, and a few others

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: different codebase that added dPoW

Author: Oszy#5734
Content: oh yes chips

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess they can always add the nSPV extentions, but that is more work. runtime forks will get it automatically

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Interesting that it needs dPoW for it to work

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Any chain that is aiming for adoption and scalability while wanting lite wallets will need dpow

Author: Cryptoon#3362
Content: Seems like this alone would create a very strong usecase for KMD...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, 1000 chains wanting dPoW is not so crazy and if each buys 10k KMD so they cover annual notarization costs via the rewards...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is a big if, but at least in the realm of possible, if we can get a lot of ecosystem projects

Author: Markus#5464
Content: What does this in the end mean? In what ways does it improve already existing spv

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the difference between needing 2GB vs 20kb to 200kb?

Author: Markus#5464
Content: Alright

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: getting notarized SPV security at API wallet speeds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: basically the best of both worlds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: both speed and security can be achieved. essentially nSPV node would be very very close security model as a full node would be

Author: Markus#5464
Content: Ok i see

Author: Markus#5464
Content: nice

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and this allows basically arbitrary scalability of the user base

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: electrum wallets dont

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and it is a fully decentralized nSPV infrastructure that uses the existing full nodes

Author: ùôäùôûùô£ùô†#3612
Content: The scalability is unheard of... with SPV the download size still grows as the chain grows. With nSPV the download size stays limited to last dPoW header plus subsequent headers....

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but enough people complain about the time it takes to sync the chain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so this allows people to sync to the latest notarized headers and know it is the mainchain, without needing any but a few headers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and yes the new address without any utxo, just needs that latest one or two notarizations to "sync up" to the mainchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a few seconds at most

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: especially for a manychain universe, the time and resources it takes to be able to transact on the chain is an important metric

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for each utxo, you need the prior notarization and the following

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 10 to 20 headers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: per utxo

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just the ones between notarizations of that utxo

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: let us consider a utxo at height 1000005 and assume notarizations happened at 1000000 and 1000010
